ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] fixed temperature profile
ygData.msgSnippet: Sergey, All you need to do is call setProfile before calling solve .  For example, the Python flame demo script flame2.py could be modified as follows:

Subject: Re: [cantera] fixed temperature profile

Sergey,

All you need to do is call 'setProfile' before calling 'solve'.  For  
example, the Python flame demo script 'flame2.py' could be modified  
as follows:

f.set(energy = 'off')
f.setRefineCriteria(ratio = 10.0, slope = 1, curve = 1)
f.setMaxJacAge(50, 50)
f.setTimeStep(1.0e-5, [1, 2, 5, 10, 20])

#---------- inserted lines -----------

# make a list of fractional distances (i.e., 0 = burner, 1 = opposite  
end of domain)
# where T will be specified

locations = [0.0, 0.1, 0.12, 0.13, 0.15, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 0.8, 0.9,  
0.99, 1.0]

# a list of T values corresponding to the positions above

temperatures = [400.0, 450.0,  (skipping intermediate values),  2000.0]

# call setProfile to fix the temperatures at these locations
f.setProfile('T', locations, temperatures)

#-----------------------------------------
f.solve(loglevel, refine_grid)



A few things to note:

1.  The BurnerFlame class has a method 'init()' that sets default  
initial temperature and species profiles.  But this method is not  
invoked if 'setProfile' is
called by the user.  So this means that if you set one profile  
(temperature), you need to set profiles for the species too. These  
can be very simple - the init()
method uses only 3-point profiles.  It is worth taking a look at  
BurnerFlame.py in the Cantera python package to see how this is done  
there. To set species profiles, use the species name in the call to  
setProfile:

loc = [0, 0.5, 1.0]
x = [0.01, 0.04, 0.0]
f.setProfile('OH', loc, x)


2. For the species profiles, they are only used for the initial  
estimate of the solution.  But for temperature, as long as the energy  
equation is disabled [ set(energy  = 'off') ] then this profile will  
be used as the fixed temperature profile throughout the solution.

3. Each profile can use a different array of locations. These values  
will be interpolated onto the actual grid, and in the case of  
temperature will be re-interpolated every time the grid is refined.  
For this reason, you will probably want to specify temperature on a  
grid with many points (corresponding to experimental data points),  
but use a very small grid to specify the initial species profiles.

Hope this helps.

Dave




On Jun 10, 2006, at 12:22 AM, Sergey Cheskis wrote:

> I am just starting my move from chemkin to cantera. I would  
> appreciate very
> much if somebody can explain me how can I make a calculation of a  
> burner
> stabilized flame with an experimentally measured temperature  
> profile. As I
> understand, in the demos (both python and matlab) the temperature  
> profile is
> calculated assuming the flame to be adiabatic. What do I need to  
> change in
> the demos (matlab and/or python) in order to used a fixed temperature
> profile?
> Thank you
> Sergey
